content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Select all the values for \(r\) that indicate a positive slope for the line of best fit.

Correct! 1, 0.5, 0.8

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are 1, 0.5, 0.8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. Select all the values for \(r\) that indicate a negative slope for the line of best fit.

Correct! –1, –0.87, –0.24

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are –1, –0.87, –0.24. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. The correlation coefficient, \(r\), is given for several different linear models for a data set. Order the values starting with the best fit of the data to a linear model and ending with the weakest fit of the data to a linear model.
0.4, –0.85, 0.72, –0.31

  1. First value (best fit) of the data to a linear model.


Correct! –0.85

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is –0.85. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Second value of the data to a linear model.


Correct! 0.72

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0.72. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Third value of the data to a linear model.


Correct! 0.4

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0.4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Fourth (weakest fit) of the data to a linear model.


Correct! –0.31

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is –0.31. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. The correlation coefficient, \(r\), is given for several different linear models for a data set. Order the values starting with the best fit of the data to a linear model and ending with the weakest fit of the data to a linear model.
–0.65, 0.47, –1, 0.89

  1. First value (best fit) of the data to a linear model.


Correct! –1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is –1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Second value of the data to a linear model.


Correct! 0.89

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0.89. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Third value of the data to a linear model.


Correct! –0.65

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is –0.65. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Fourth (weakest fit) of the data to a linear model.


Correct! 0.47

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0.47. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


5.Match the following scatter plots to the correct correlation coefficient from the following:

\(r=0.67\)

\(r=-0.33\)

\(r=0.88\)

\(r= -0.79\)


  1. Scatter Plot A

Correct! \( r=0.88\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.4.3–3.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(r=0.88\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Scatter Plot B

Correct! \( r=-0.79\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.4.3–3.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(r=-0.79\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Scatter Plot C

Correct! \( r=-0.33\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.4.3–3.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(r=-0.33\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  1. Scatter Plot D

Correct! \(r=0.67\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.4.3–3.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(r=0.67\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Which of the following correlation coefficients would best describe this scatter plot?

Correct! \(-0.87\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.4.2–3.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(-0.87\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Which of the following has the stronger linear relationship? Explain.

Scatter Plot A:

Scatter Plot B:

Correct! Scatter plot B because the points in the scatter plot are closer to forming a linear relationship.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is scatter plot B because the points in the scatter plot are closer to forming a linear relationship. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
